thread.title: MARKET SNAPSHOT: China Rate Cut Adds To Rally Fever On Wall Street
thread.title_full: MARKET SNAPSHOT: China Rate Cut Adds To Rally Fever On Wall Street

author: morningstar.com
title: MARKET SNAPSHOT: China Rate Cut Adds To Rally Fever On Wall Street
text:
By Anora Mahmudova and Barbara Kollmeyer, MarketWatch
Amazon, Microsoft and Alphabet soar in premarket trading
U.S. stocks traded sharply higher on Friday as investors cheered an interest-rate cut from China's central bank and better-than-expected earnings results from heavyweight tech companies including Alphabet Inc., Microsoft Corp. and Amazon.com.
The main indexes were on track to book solid weekly gains for the fourth week in a row.
The S&P 500 surged 19 points, or 1%, to 2,072, turning positive for the year as it erased losses that sent it to correction territory in late August. On Friday, eight of its 10 main sectors were trading higher. Energy and utilities were the only laggards, while technology and heath-care stocks surged.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average jumped 131 points, or 0.9%, to 17,651, with 24 of its 30 members trading higher. The Nasdaq Composite outperformed other indexes, advancing 108 points, or 2.2%, to 5,029.04.
"While promises of easy policy from most important central banks -- the ECB, Fed and China has jolted markets higher, it is encouraging to see solid earnings results from tech, consumer discretionary and health-care companies," said Michael Arone, chief investment strategist for State Street Global Advisors' US Intermediary Business.
Global equity markets were already heading higher thanks to better-than-expected corporate results and hints of more easing measures from European Central Bank President Mario Draghi on Thursday (http://www.marketwatch.com/story/ecbs-draghi-opens-door-for-more-qe-in-december-2015-10-22).
Friday's risk appetite was further fueled by the People's Bank of China's decision to cut its one-year deposit rate by 25 basis points to 1.5% (http://www.marketwatch.com/story/pboc-cuts-benchmark-interest-rates-2015-10-23). The PBOC lowered its one-year lending rate by 25 basis points to 4.35%.
Read: The best six months for stocks is about to begin (http://www.marketwatch.com/story/the-best-six-months-for-stocks-is-about-to-begin-2015-10-23)
Investors piled into riskier assets such as equities, sending European markets sharply higher. Meanwhile, government bonds sold off. The yield on the 10-year Treasury note rose 6 basis points to 2.09%, implying a rotation from bonds to stocks.
Thursday's relief rally for Wall Street retraced about half the "panic attack" since China devalued the yuan, said Ed Yardeni, chief investment strategist at Yardeni Research, in a note.
With central banks in the spotlight, more attention will now turn to the Federal Open Market Committee meeting Oct. 27 and 28, and the Bank of Japan's monetary policy meeting on Oct. 30.
Upbeat tech: Shares of Amazon(AMZN) jumped 7.4% after the e-commerce giant announced a surprise profit for the third quarter (http://www.marketwatch.com/story/amazon-posts-surprise-profit-while-sales-surge-2015-10-22-16485258) and forecast an operating profit for the holiday quarter.
Alphabet (GOOGL), formerly known as Google, announced its first-ever stock buyback plan (http://blogs.marketwatch.com/thetell/2015/10/22/live-blog-google-to-report-first-earnings-as-alphabet/). It will spend more than $5 billion buying back shares. Shares rallied 8%.
Read: Are tech rebels Amazon and Alphabet finally growing up? (http://www.marketwatch.com/story/are-tech-rebels-amazon-and-alphabet-finally-growing-up-2015-10-22)
(http://www.marketwatch.com/story/are-tech-rebels-amazon-and-alphabet-finally-growing-up-2015-10-22)Microsoft(MSFT) reported better-than-expected profit and revenue (http://www.marketwatch.com/story/microsoft-profit-buoyed-by-lower-costs-2015-10-22) late Thursday, and shares surged 11%.
Also in the news Friday, Twitter Inc.'s(TWTR) chief executive officer Jack Dorsey, said he would give nearly $200 million of his own shares (http://www.marketwatch.com/story/twitters-jack-dorsey-gives-workers-nearly-200-million-of-his-own-shares-2015-10-23) -- or 1% of the company -- to the employee stock pool. Twitter shares rose 3.1%.
Procter & Gamble Co.(PG) will report results later Friday.
Other markets: The extra boost from China rate cuts added to already strong gains for the Stoxx Europe 600 index (http://www.marketwatch.com/story/european-stocks-on-pace-to-third-straight-weekly-gain-2015-10-23), which was headed for its third straight weekly gain. It was up 2.2% as the market coasted on the potential for more stimulus from the ECB. A flash reading of October manufacturing activity in the eurozone (http://www.marketwatch.com/story/eurozone-pmi-gains-suggests-no-china-impact-yet-2015-10-23) came in higher than expected.
Closing ahead of that PBOC move, Asian markets (http://www.marketwatch.com/story/nikkei-hang-seng-climb-on-hopes-for-more-stimulus-in-europe-2015-10-23) also saw sharp gains across the board, with the Shanghai Composite Index rising 1.2%. The Nikkei 225 index closed up 2.1% as the Japanese yen continued to weaken against the U.S. dollar (http://www.marketwatch.com/story/euro-extends-losses-investors-turn-to-next-weeks-fomc-meeting-2015-10-23).
The euro also remained on a weaker footing against the U.S. currency.
Gold prices reversed earlier gains and fell 0.5% to $1,160.70 an ounce, while crude oil (http://www.marketwatch.com/story/oil-prices-rise-but-stronger-dollar-lurks-in-the-background-2015-10-23) dropped 2.2% to $44.32 a barrel.
 23, 2015 10:41 ET (14:41
